description: Problems with contradictory or flawed premises - model should identify the flaw

problems.problem: A triangle has angles measuring 60°, 70°, and 80°. What is the length of the longest side if the shortest side is 5 cm?
problems.expected_behavior: Identify that 60+70+80=210° which is impossible for a triangle

problems.problem: A car travels 100 km in 2 hours at a constant speed. It then travels another 100 km in 1 hour at the same constant speed. Calculate the constant speed.
problems.flaw: Contradictory speeds (50 km/h and 100 km/h) claimed to be the same
problems.expected_behavior: Identify that the same constant speed cannot produce both 50 km/h and 100 km/h

problems.problem: In a class of 30 students, 20 passed math, 25 passed science, and 5 failed both subjects. How many passed both?
problems.flaw: Numbers don't add up: 20+25-both+5=30 means both=20, but then 25 science students can't exist if only 25 total passed
problems.expected_behavior: Identify the inconsistency using inclusion-exclusion: 20+25-both = 30-5 = 25, so both=20, but this means all math passers also passed science

problems.problem: A father is currently 30 years old and his son is 10. In how many years will the father be twice as old as the son? Given: The father is always exactly 3 times the son's age.
problems.flaw: Father is currently 3× son's age (30=3×10), but asked when he'll be 2× while maintaining 3× ratio
problems.expected_behavior: Identify that the 'always 3×' constraint contradicts the '2×' question

problems.problem: A perpetual motion machine produces 100 watts of power continuously with no energy input. How much energy will it produce in 24 hours?
problems.flaw: Perpetual motion machines violate thermodynamics - they cannot exist
problems.expected_behavior: Identify that the premise violates laws of thermodynamics and is impossible
